title: Oregon State to co-lead $30 million USDA regional food business center - Oregon State University
summary: Oregon State University will co-lead a $30 million U.S. Department of Agriculture regional food business center that will support farmers, ranchers and other food-related businesses to access new markets. The Northwest and Rocky Mountain Regional Food Business Center will focus on four areas: Strengthening local supply chains for animal proteins, connecting and scaling food entrepreneurs, supporting climate-resilient agriculture, and “right-sizing” investment and infrastructure.

title: Bill would shield recyclers from PFAS cleanup costs - Resource Recycling
summary: The article reports on a bill introduced in the U.S. Senate that protects composting, recycling and garbage facilities from cleanup cost liability of a class of chemicals called PFAS. The bill exempts certain facilities from liability under the federal Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, commonly known as CERCLA. Several organizations voiced support for the bill.
green_innovation: TRUE. The bill promotes environmental sustainability by protecting composting, recycling, and garbage facilities from cleanup cost liability related to PFAS contamination.

title: UM Announces New U.S. Leadership Across Growth, Strategy, Planning, Intelligence, Client Services and Operations - PR Newswire
summary: UM, a global media agency network of IPG Mediabrands, has announced new U.S. leadership to bolster the agency's commitment to upleveling craft across all practices. The appointments include Grant Ogburn to Chief Growth Officer, Myia Thompkins to Chief Strategy Officer, Preston Larson to Chief Planning Officer, Brendon Volpe to Chief Intelligence Officer and the elevations of Erin Quintana to Chief Client Officer and Jennifer Wadeyka to Chief Operating Officer.   This announcement follows several accolades UM has recently received, including being named a FORTUNE Best Workplace in Advertising & Marketing, a Top Workplace in the US by Great Places to Work several times over and distinctions for "Inclusive Workplace" and "Sustainability Standout" in Campaign's 2023 Agency Performance Review.

title: The challenges of greenhouse gas accounting in the UK's waste and recycling sector - Ricardo PLC
summary: The waste and recycling sector is making progress on the journey to net zero but faces challenges in collecting, analysing and reporting emissions. The sector contributes to avoided emissions across the supply chains of other industries, but cannot claim credits for these. Waste management companies face challenges in data collection and reporting, as well as a lack of a framework on accounting for avoided emissions.

title: Hershey releases environmental, social and governance report highlighting sustainability targets - Confectionery Production
summary: The Hershey Company's 2022 ESG Report highlights progress on sustainability goals, including reducing environmental impact and promoting diversity. The company's Cocoa For Good strategy aims to invest $500 million by 2030 to improve cocoa farming communities, and it has achieved 77% cocoa sourcing visibility by volume in Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana. Hershey is also committed to reducing its environmental impact, with a goal to achieve a 50% absolute reduction in Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 against a 2018 baseline.
green_innovation: TRUE, The company's Cocoa For Good strategy, which aims to invest $500 million by 2030 to improve cocoa farming communities, can be considered a green innovation as it contributes to environmental sustainability goals.

green_product: FALSE, The article does not describe a specific product that meets the criteria to be a green product.
green_process: TRUE, The company's transition to using rice husks as biofuel to power production at its India plant can be considered a green process as it reduces carbon intensity and contributes to environmental sustainability.

title: B.C. government pledges additional $25 million for coastal cleanup - Aldergrove Star
summary: The British Columbia government has invested $25 million into its Clean Coast, Clean Waters Initiative to remove derelict vessels and clean up marine debris along 4,600 km of shoreline, creating over 1,700 jobs. The initiative has removed 1,500 tonnes of marine debris, including 118 derelict vessels, and 64% of shoreline materials have been recycled or upcycled. The Coastal First Nations-Great Bear Initiative will receive $7.5 million to support ecosystem restoration and protection through sustainable resource management practices.
